rsbNotes.title: Ps 44
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 44 In this psalm an alternation between “I” and “we” suggests that the psalmist is the king of Israel. It is not possible to identify a special occasion for the writing of the psalm, and it can be applied to many different occasions.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:9
rsbNotes.text: 44:9 you have rejected us and disgraced us. God was with Israel at Jericho, but now He does not bless the army with His leadership. This resulted in their easy defeat.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:12
rsbNotes.text: 44:12 You have sold your people for a trifle. These are bold words, a striking example of the honesty of the psalmist’s approach to God in prayer.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:19
rsbNotes.text: 44:19 shadow of death. Normally reserved for God’s enemies (Nah. 1:8).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:22
rsbNotes.text: 44:22 for your sake. The world seems utterly turned around. The people have not forgotten God, yet they suffer for His sake. Paul quotes this verse in Rom. 8:36.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:23
rsbNotes.text: 44:23 Awake. The psalmist prays as if God were asleep and unaware of Israel’s plight. This daring language reflects the writer’s frustration. The usual cry to God before battle is “Arise” (Ps. 7:6).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 44:26
rsbNotes.text: 44:26 for the sake of your steadfast love. Specifically, God’s lovingkindness to those with whom He is in covenantal relationship (e.g., Abraham, Gen. 17:1–9).
